Q6Comment: Oklahoma law does not allow for registering anyone to vote automatically.  An offer for voter registration is made by state government agencies offering voter registration as required by NVRA. Each agency that receives these Statements are required to retain them for 24 months from the date they are signed  Most state agencies in Oklahoma use a paper-based procedure to offer voter registration to clients and clients may decline the offer of voter registration on said paper form. Only DPS (Dept. of Public Safety) uses any type of automation in the process.  Beginning in 2017, in connection with driver license renewals and changes of address on driver licenses, DPS began transmitting electronic data weekly to the State Election Board, but new registrations were executed on a paper voter registration form.  Earlier this year, DPS began implementing a long-awaited modernization plan that will result in all NVRA registration activities in driver license examination locations (for new drivers licenses in Oklahoma) and in motor license agencies (where most changes of name or address and all renewals occur) that moves their NVRA compliance activities to a fully digital process.  Data from is received by the State Election Board daily.

Such registration application are entered into the voter registration system and the system holds the application until the applicant's 18th birthday occurs.  At that time, the application is automatically activated, a voter ID card is printed the next time the ID card process runs, and the voter's name will be in the appropriate precinct registry on election day.
Q11Comment: An "active voter" is one who voted, in-person or by absentee ballot, in at least one election conducted by a County Election Board since the second previous General Election, or a voter who has updated his or her voter registration information, or who has returned an address confirmation notice response.  An "inactive" voter is one who has not voted or updated voter registration during a period including two General Elections, who has not responded to an address confirmation notice response or whose address confirmation was returned undeliverable by USPS.
Q12Comment: County Election Board personnel are responsible for cancelling voter registrations for routine reasons: death; notice of registration in another jurisdiction (another county or another state); conviction of a felony in federal or state court; at the request of a voter; notice of determination by a court of a voter's incapacity; and notice of surrender of an OK driver license in another state. Some information of this type is received electronically at the State Election Board and is entered into the voter registration system, but only County Election Board personnel have the authority to cancel such registrations.  The State Election Board cancels voter registrations under only two circumstances: "true duplicates," which occur when the same voter is registered in two or more counties in Oklahoma and the removal of registrations for voters who did not return an address confirmation notice, or whose notice was returned undelivered, and who have not voted or updated registration since the second prior General Election. The process includes privacy warnings and fraud warnings as required by state and federal law.    Each customer must choose if they wish to complete the registration process with the following question:  "If you are an eligible Virginia resident, the following process will register you to vote or update your current voter registration.
